value.text: The NY Times and other media that treated Gay's academic misconduct as a national story were an essential part of the right wing campaign to have her removed. Compare how they treated the President of Stanford, who faced much more serious accusations of academic misconduct.

I am going to start 2024 by celebrating scientists in my print collection whose birthdays aren’t known starting with one of the earliest recorded women in science, Peseshet. 🐡🧪👩🏾‍🔬 #histsci She is described in the elaborate Saqqara tomb of her son Akhethotep, a royal official & overseer of priests, 🧵1/

images.alt: My linocut of Peseshet, ancient Egyptian woman physician dispensing medicine with hieroglyphs in dark red and blue spelling out her name and profession.
My linocut of Peseshet, ancient Egyptian woman physician dispensing medicine with hieroglyphs in dark red and blue spelling out her name and profession.

record.text: I post these almost every day, for lots of folks!

Lynn Conway, electricial engineer and computer scientist, co-architect of the VLSI design revolution, and transgender activist, was born OTD in 1938.

She invented Dynamic Instruction Scheduling at IBM, but IBM fired her when they learned she was transitioning. 🧪 👩‍🔬

Photo: Lynn Conway

images.alt: A woman with red hair in a black shirt and light grey skirt, smiling, standing in front of a curtained window and floral wallpaper, behind a striped cushioned chair or sofa and dark wooden table with vase and bouquet of white, blue & pink flowers.

A woman with red hair in a black shirt and light grey skirt, smiling, standing in front of a curtained window and floral wallpaper, behind a striped cushioned chair or sofa and dark wooden table with vase and bouquet of white, blue & pink flowers.

record.text: Oh God, don't just post things like this out of the blue - I thought she must have died when I saw it!  :(

record.text: Edwin Hubble announced OTD in 1925 that Andromeda and other spiral nebulae were in fact separate galaxies outside the Milky Way, in a paper read to an AAS meeting by H.N. Russell. The Universe was far larger than what many astronomers had imagined; more than just our little island of stars. 🧪 🔭

images.alt: A black and white photo of M31, the Andromeda galaxy. It is characterized by spiral arms and dark lanes of dust and gas, with a bright center.
A black and white photo of M31, the Andromeda galaxy. It is characterized by spiral arms and dark lanes of dust and gas, with a bright center.

value.text:
In Manly Wade Wellman’s “Silver John” stories, John mentions a book called “Long Lost Friend” as the source of some of his knowledge. I recently learned that it’s a real book, the full text is online, and it has a spell to make a dog like you.

sacred-texts.com/ame/pow/inde...

record.text: My Steamboat Willie is leading the steamboat pilots' union in a terrorist campaign against the corporation that controls the riverboats.

value.text: My Steamboat Willie can’t remember when he first stepped on the boat, or how he got there, or the name of the cursed river. All he knows is that there are always new souls lined up on the shore, waiting to be ferried across, coins plucked from their eyes to pay the way.
MY Steamboat Willie runs a cannibalistic multi-level marketing cult and also is a violent cheese addict

A thing I didn't anticipate about parenting is when your kid gets to the age they can have playdates and they just go over to a friend's house for HOURS. And another time a kid comes to your house and occupies your kid for HOURS and you just provide snacks and general supervision. It's great!

record.text:
Yvonne Madelaine Brill was born OTD in 1924. She was a rocket scientist who invented the hydrazine resistojet, which increased the payload capacity of satellites by reducing the weight of propellant they require. JWST uses hydrazine thrusters! 🧪 🔭 👩‍🔬

Photo: W. McNamee/Getty

images.alt: Color photo of Brill receiving the National Medal of Technology and Innovation from President Obama in 2011. He is wearing a dark suit and smiling at the camera. She is wearing a floral top and smiling at the camera. A medal with a red, white, and blue ribbon hangs around her neck.
Schematic drawing of the hydrazine thruster from the patent application.

Color photo of Brill receiving the National Medal of Technology and Innovation from President Obama in 2011. He is wearing a dark suit and smiling at the camera. She is wearing a floral top and smiling at the camera. A medal with a red, white, and blue ribbon hangs around her neck.
Schematic drawing of the hydrazine thruster from the patent application.

Biggest astrophysics news of 2023? 🔭🧪

IMO, gotta be the strongest evidence yet of nanohertz-regime gravitational waves, announced by global pulsar timing array teams in June!

A little biased here though (am an author on papers!)

www.spaceaustralia.com/feature/aust... 

📸 @astronerdika.bsky.social

images.alt: Graphic showing the Earth at the centre of a warped space-time grid. On the grid, surrounding the Earth are several pulsars whose beams are being distorted with space-time. In the distance, and on the edges of the image, are swirling binary black holes.

Graphic showing the Earth at the centre of a warped space-time grid. On the grid, surrounding the Earth are several pulsars whose beams are being distorted with space-time. In the distance, and on the edges of the image, are swirling binary black holes.

record.text: Man, I was explaining to my 11yo that “Hey Ya!” came out “8 or 9 years ago” and my wife got this real serious look and put her hand on my shoulder and said “No. It’s been twenty years.”
I gasped and put my hand over my mouth.

record.text:
The first known photo of the Andromeda galaxy, at the time thought to be a nebula, was taken by astronomer Isaac Roberts OTD in 1888.

The image, captured with his 20" reflector, reveals a clear spiral structure. But scientists assumed M31 was a gas cloud within our galaxy. 🧪 🔭

Image: Isaac Roberts

images.alt: Black and white photo of the Andromeda galaxy. A bright central bulge is surrounded by a fainter spiral with dark dust lanes. The background is full of stars and other, smaller galaxies.
Black and white photo of the Andromeda galaxy. A bright central bulge is surrounded by a fainter spiral with dark dust lanes. The background is full of stars and other, smaller galaxies.

I can add a colorful bit. I had a prof in college who'd met him. He had a long string of minor car accidents: he was always working problems in his  head, and was once late for class because "a tree stepped into my path." A tree-lined intersection near campus was known as "von Neumann's Corners."
Polymath simply isn’t broad enough of a term.

value.text:
Mathematician, physicist, and computer scientist, the great omnimath John von Neumann was born OTD in 1903.

He considered his quantum mechanics contributions to be most important. To get a sense of the breadth of his work look at his Wikipedia “known for” list. 🧪

images.alt: A photo portrait of Jon von Neumann. He is wearing a dark wool suit, seated and looking at the camera.
John von Neumann’s “Known for” list from Wikipedia. It is too long to repeat here. The full list can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_von_Neumann
A photo portrait of Jon von Neumann. He is wearing a dark wool suit, seated and looking at the camera.
John von Neumann’s “Known for” list from Wikipedia. It is too long to repeat here. The full list can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_von_Neumann

At a 1964 MIT symposium, Chien-Shiung Wu commented: “I wonder whether the tiny atoms and nuclei, or the mathematical symbols, or the DNA molecules have any preference for either masculine or feminine treatment.” 🧪 👩‍🔬

Image: Smithsonian Institution

images.alt: Chien-Shiung Wu standing alongside the beam line of her experimental apparatus with two collaborators. They are all wearing lab coats. She is looking directly at the camera while appearing to make an adjustment to the apparatus with her right hand.

value.text:
A team led by physicist Chien-Shiung Wu obtained the first experimental confirmation of parity violation, in the decay of Cobalt-60, OTD in 1956.

Her theory colleagues received a Nobel for the prediction, but Wu – who actually observed the effect – was left off the prize. 🧪 👩‍🔬

Image: Smithsonian

images.alt: Chien-Shiung Wu standing behind the beam line of her apparatus. She is wearing a white lab coat and smiling at the camera.
Chien-Shiung Wu standing behind the beam line of her apparatus. She is wearing a white lab coat and smiling at the camera.

record.text:
Reminder in case you and your friends/fam need this as much as mine have this week:

Any adults who test positive for Covid or flu (or both 🫠) in the US can get free telemed + free treatment (like Tamiflu or Paxlovid) from this NIH-funded program: 

test2treat.org

images.alt: Green and black text reads “Home test to treat program”. A roof peaks over the “o” in home.
Green and black text reads “Home test to treat program”. A roof peaks over the “o” in home.

record.text: (He didn’t use it for her specifically. Rather, he offered it as a term to address a lack of unity among the physical sciences.)
In an 1834 review of her book “On the Connexion of the Physical Sciences,” William Whewell first used the term “scientist” in print. He had coined it the previous year. 🧪 👩‍🔬

value.text:
Mary Somerville was born OTD in 1780. She was a scientist, writer, and artist; the first woman (with Caroline Herschel) to belong to the Royal Astronomical Society; and the first signature on Mill’s 1868 Women’s Suffrage petition. 🧪 👩‍🔬

Image: self portrait (Somerville College, Oxford)

images.alt: A self-portrait painted by Mary Somerville. She is seated in a red chair, holding what appears to be paper and quill in her hands. Her brown hair is pulled back under a bonnet and she is wearing a long gray dress.

A self-portrait painted by Mary Somerville. She is seated in a red chair, holding what appears to be paper and quill in her hands. Her brown hair is pulled back under a bonnet and she is wearing a long gray dress.

record.text: From this lovely remembrance of John Conway I learned that, by virtue of once shaking Conway’s hand after a seminar, I am only four handshakes removed from Napoleon. Perhaps some of you are, as well.

external.title: John Conway Solved Mathematical Problems With His Bare Hands
external.description: The legendary mathematician, who died on April 11, was curious, colorful and one of the greatest problem-solvers of his generation.

value.text: Mathematician John Conway was born OTD in 1937. He made broad and profound contributions across all of mathematics, but he is maybe best known by the general public for his "game of life" cellular automaton. Conway died a few years ago, from COVID-19. 🧪
